blogs.title: BC government to officially start accepting rideshare applications this September | Urbanized
blogs.description:
The BC government has officially announced it will open the door to allow rideshare companies to apply for operation in BC under to the Passenger Transportation Board by this September. See also

- TransLink launches new bookable on-demand bus service, similar to rideshare
- BC rejects Class 5 licence rideshare driver recommendation despite committee findings
- BC transportation minister would 'love' rideshare rollout to be faster
- Passenger Transportation Board finds ‘public need’ for ridesharing in BC
- How hard is it to get a Class 4 licence? You'll need it to drive an Uber or Lyft in BC On Monday, the province said the new regulations are intended to provide a framework for what companies can expect in advance of applying to the Passen

blogs.title: B.C.'s new ride-hail licensing too complicated for prospective drivers, advocates fear | CBC News
blogs.description: The province is getting pushback from ride-hailing advocates who say the new rules and regulations announced by the B.C. government Monday make it difficult for prospective drivers to become licensed.

blogs.title: Lyft set to launch ride-hailing in Vancouver area before end of the year | CBC News
blogs.description: Ride-hailing company Lyft says it's confident it will begin operations in fall 2019.

blogs.title: Rules for B.C. ride-sharing industry released: No restrictions on fleet sizes or surge pricing
blogs.description: Ridesharing companies in British Columbia will not be restricted by fleet sizes, will not have a cap price and can operate in much larger regional boundaries than taxi companies can.

blogs.title: No fleet-size limits or price surge restrictions for ride-hailing companies in B.C.
blogs.description: The final rules on geographic borders, supply caps and pricing are set for ride-hailing companies that want to apply to operate in B.C.

blogs.title: Bring on Uber: Company applies to operate in Vancouver
blogs.description: The company follows a similar announcement from Lyft earlier this month, as B.C. finalizes its guidelines for ride-hailing companies.

blogs.title: B.C. Taxi Association considers going to court over ride-hailing rules
blogs.description: “There are thousands of families that depend directly on the taxi industry for their livelihood in Metro Vancouver and other parts of B.C.” — B.C. Taxi Association president Mohan Kang.

blogs.title: Uber and Lyft have officially applied to launch rideshare in Metro Vancouver | Urbanized
blogs.description:
Both global rideshare giants confirmed to Daily Hive that they have officially submitted their formal applications to launch rideshare in strategic markets of BC. See also: - BC Transportation Minister concerned about rideshare congestion, lack of cap limits
- All-Tesla long-haul rideshare service announces plans for BC launch
- Rideshare could put a dent in Vancouver’s high level of carshare usage
- Surrey mayor says he “doesn’t support” ride-hailing in BC The Passenger Transportation Board (PTB) began accepting rideshare service applications on Tuesday, and both Uber and Lyft submitted their applications on the same day. At this time, Uber and Lyft are only planning to launch their services in Region 1 of the Transportation Network Servic

blogs.title: Taxi companies ask B.C. court to toss out rules governing Uber, Lyft operations
blogs.description: Taxi companies in B.C. are challenging rules governing how Uber, Lyft and other ride-sharing companies can operate in the province.

blogs.title: Unlike Uber and Lyft, Kater intends to offer ride-hailing across B.C.
blogs.description: Unlike two notable American tech giants, B.C.-based Kater Technologies Inc. says it wants to operate throughout the entire province when ride-hailing services finally arrive on the West Coast.
